Package me.wouterkistemaker.eventmanager

Class EventManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wouterkistemaker.eventmanager.EventManager
  • public final class EventManager
extends java.lang.Object
    Represents the main functional unit of this library. It allows the user to call Events, and add EventListeners that will respond accordingly to the called Events. After initialization, one will have to manually start the EventManager by calling the start()-function.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      EventManager()  

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      <T extends Event>
      void      		 callEvent​(T event)
      This method is used to call an Event, which means that the Event is added to the Queue so that, in case of overloads the Events will be executed in the right order
      protected <T extends Event>
      void      		 executeEvent​(T event)
      This method executes an Event.
      void forceStop()
      This method instantly shuts down the Thread of the EventLoop without checking of it is still running or not.
      void register​(EventListener eventListener)
      This method registers a new EventListener to the List of EventListener
      void start()
      This method initializes the Thread that is used with Runnable = EventLoop
      void stop()
      This method checks whether the Thread of the EventLoop is still running or not.

    • Constructor Detail

      • EventManager

        public EventManager()

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public final void start()
        This method initializes the Thread that is used with Runnable = EventLoop

        After initializing the Thread it calls the 'start()' of the thread which will start the Runnable to run.

      • stop

        public final void stop()
        This method checks whether the Thread of the EventLoop is still running or not. If the Thread is still running, the method accepts this, and doesn't do anything.

        If the Thread is not running, it calls the forceStop() method that simply closes the Thread and resets the value that is used in this Class

      • forceStop

        public final void forceStop()
        This method instantly shuts down the Thread of the EventLoop without checking of it is still running or not.

        After interrupting, it resets the value of the Thread that is being used in this Class

      • register

        public final void register​(EventListener eventListener)
        This method registers a new EventListener to the List of EventListener
        Parameters:
        eventListener - The EventListener that is being registered to the List in this class.

      • executeEvent

        protected final <T extends Event> void executeEvent​(T event)
        This method executes an Event. By doing so, the method iterates over all registered EventListener and checks whether these EventListener contains a method that can be used to invoke on the called Event

        If there is no method that can be invoked on the called Event

        Parameters:
        event - An instance of an Class that is a superclass from Event

      • callEvent

        public final <T extends Event> void callEvent​(T event)
        This method is used to call an Event, which means that the Event is added to the Queue so that, in case of overloads the Events will be executed in the right order
        Parameters:
        event - Instance of the event to be added to the Queue in the EventLoop
